docs.snippet: A Toronto entrepreneur will try to take over a 5,000-square-foot screen in Times Square with his cellphone on Tuesday at 8 p.m....
docs.lead_paragraph: Adi Isakovic, a Toronto entrepreneur, will attempt to take over a 5,000-square-foot screen in Times Square with his cellphone on Tuesday at 8 p.m. Mr. Isakovic's company, TubeMote, wants to allow people to use their phones as universal remotes, controlling not only their televisions and home security systems, but also public screens in elevators, stadium scoreboards - and screens in Times Square. He rented a few minutes of screen space to show what he can do. Read the full article on the Bits blog.
docs.abstract: A Toronto entrepreneur will try to take over a 5,000-square-foot screen in Times Square with his cellphone on Tuesday at 8 p.m.

docs.snippet: A 50-foot high image of Adi Isakovic's dog, Cookie, appeared on a jumbo screen in Times Square several minutes after 8 p.m. last night. Cookie sniffed around for a bit, then Mr. Isakovic pressed a button on his phone and the screen switched to a v...
docs.lead_paragraph: A 50-foot high image of Adi Isakovic's dog, Cookie, appeared on a jumbo screen in Times Square several minutes after 8 p.m. last night. Cookie sniffed around for a bit, then Mr. Isakovic pressed a button on his phone and the screen switched to a video of his wife, Tania, on vacation in Maui. Mr. Isakovic's experiment with controlling a 5000-square foot screen in Times Square with his phone, which Bits wrote about yesterday, hit a snag when he tried to stream live video. When Mr. Isakovic tried the trick, intended to mimic a hoax that became a viral hit on YouTube last week, the screen went white, and stayed that way.
docs.abstract: Bits blog notes snag encountered by Adi Isakovic when he projected an image from his mobile phone on 50-foot screen in Times Square to mimic hoax that became viral hit on YouTube; photo (S)

headline.main: From a Little Phone, a Jumbo Image

docs.snippet: A man from Toronto will try to take over a 5,000-square-foot screen in Times Square with his phone on Tuesday night, replicating a hoax video that drew millions of viewers online....
docs.lead_paragraph: Adi Isakovic called MTV last fall to propose a deal: he would stream live video, text messages and other content directly from his phone onto the company's gargantuan video screen in Times Square. The demonstration would give Mr. Isakovic the chance show off a technology he had been developing for years, while MTV would place itself at the forefront of a movement, attracting a wave of innovators eager to develop the next generation of public art and advertising.
docs.abstract: A man from Toronto will try to take over a 5,000-square-foot screen in Times Square with his phone on Tuesday night, replicating a hoax video that drew millions of viewers online.

headline.main: Controlling Times Square's Screens With a Phone, for Real This Time

docs.snippet: Jack Shainman Gallery  513 West 20th Street, Chelsea  Through April 12      Adi Nes, an Israeli photographer, is making his New York solo debut here. But one of his pictures appeared all over the city a few years ago in advertisements for an exhib...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jack Shainman Gallery 513 West 20th Street, Chelsea Through April 12 Adi Nes, an Israeli photographer, is making his New York solo debut here. But one of his pictures appeared all over the city a few years ago in advertisements for an exhibition of new art from Israel at the Jewish Museum. It was an image of a bare-chested young man in combat boots, army fatigues and a yarmulke, flexing his muscles in front of a tent pitched in desert sand.
docs.abstract: Holland Cotter reviews Adi Nes photographs at Jack Shainman Gallery (S)
